core_concept.principle: Classical mechanics provides a complete framework for describing motion through Newton's laws, conservation principles, and the relationships between force, mass, energy, and momentum. These concepts form the foundation for understanding all macroscopic physical phenomena.
core_concept.explanation: This comprehensive review integrates the fundamental principles that govern motion from everyday objects to celestial bodies, emphasizing the mathematical structure, experimental basis, and practical applications of classical mechanics.

worked_examples.title: Rolling Ball Becomes Projectile
worked_examples.problem: A solid sphere (M=2 kg, R=0.1 m) rolls without slipping down 2 m high, 30° incline, then flies off edge. Calculate: (a) Speed at bottom, (b) Rotational energy at bottom, (c) Range if edge is 1.5 m high, (d) Time of flight.

step_by_step.explanation: Initial velocity: $v_x = v\cos30^\circ = 4.58$ m/s, $v_y = v\sin30^\circ = 2.65$ m/s upward from 1.5 m height
Rotational energy becomes additional kinetic energy in flight

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Speed at bottom = 5.29 m/s, (b) Rotational energy = 11.2 J, (c) Range = 4.67 m, (d) Time of flight = 1.02 s. Demonstrates energy conservation with transition to projectile motion.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Energy conservation with rolling and projectile motion

image.caption: Objects can transition between rolling and projectile motion

worked_examples.title: Complex Collision with Rotation
worked_examples.problem: A 0.5 kg particle moving at 8 m/s strikes and sticks to end of 1 m, 2 kg rod pivoted at center. Calculate: (a) Angular velocity after collision, (b) Energy lost, (c) Maximum angle of swing, (d) Compare with center impact.

step_by_step.explanation: Rod: $I_{rod} = \frac{1}{12}ML^2 = \frac{1}{12} \times 2 \times 1 = 0.167$ kg·m², Particle: $I_{part} = mr^2 = 0.5 \times 0.25 = 0.125$ kg·m², Total: $I_f = 0.292$ kg·m²
Energy conservation: $\frac{1}{2}I_f\omega_f^2 = (M+m)g\Delta h_{CM}$, $\Delta h_{CM} = \frac{L}{2}(1-\cos\theta)$ for small angles
If particle hits center: $I_f = 0.167$ kg·m², $\omega_f = 12.0$ rad/s, more energy transfer but different motion

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Angular velocity = 6.85 rad/s, (b) Energy lost = 9.15 J, (c) Maximum angle = 47.8°, (d) Center impact gives higher angular velocity (12.0 rad/s) but different energy distribution. Demonstrates angular momentum conservation in inelastic collisions.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Angular momentum conservation with energy loss

worked_examples.title: Complex Atwood Machine Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Atwood machine: m₁=3 kg, m₂=5 kg, pulley M=2 kg, R=0.15 m, I=0.5MR². Calculate: (a) Acceleration, (b) String tensions, (c) Angular acceleration, (d) Verify energy conservation after 2 m motion.

step_by_step.explanation: m₁: $T_1 - m_1g = m_1a$, m₂: $m_2g - T_2 = m_2a$, pulley: $(T_2 - T_1)R = I\alpha = I\frac{a}{R}$
From pulley: $T_2 - T_1 = \frac{Ia}{R^2} = \frac{0.0225a}{0.0225} = a$, Add m₁ and m₂ equations: $(m_2 - m_1)g - (T_2 - T_1) = (m_1 + m_2)a$

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Acceleration = 2.18 m/s², (b) Tensions: T₁ = 35.9 N, T₂ = 38.1 N, (c) Angular acceleration = 14.5 rad/s², (d) Energy conservation verified: ΔU = 39.2 J = K_total. Demonstrates coupled translational-rotational dynamics.

image.caption: Massive pulley affects dynamics in Atwood machine

worked_examples.title: Rolling Race Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Solid sphere, solid cylinder, and hollow cylinder (all M=1 kg, R=0.1 m) race down 3 m high, 25° incline. Calculate for each: (a) Acceleration, (b) Time to bottom, (c) Final speed, (d) Explain race outcome.

step_by_step.explanation: Sphere: $I = 0.4MR^2 = 0.004$ kg·m², Solid cylinder: $I = 0.5MR^2 = 0.005$ kg·m², Hollow cylinder: $I = MR^2 = 0.010$ kg·m²

$v = \sqrt{2aL}$, Sphere: $\sqrt{2\times2.958\times7.10} = \sqrt{42.0} = 6.48$ m/s, Cylinder: $\sqrt{2\times2.761\times7.10} = \sqrt{39.2} = 6.26$ m/s, Hollow: $\sqrt{2\times2.071\times7.10} = \sqrt{29.4} = 5.42$ m/s

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Accelerations: sphere 2.96 m/s², cylinder 2.76 m/s², hollow 2.07 m/s², (b) Times: sphere 2.19 s, cylinder 2.27 s, hollow 2.62 s, (c) Final speeds: sphere 6.48 m/s, cylinder 6.26 m/s, hollow 5.42 m/s, (d) Sphere wins, then cylinder, then hollow cylinder - mass concentration away from axis increases rotational inertia and decreases acceleration.

worked_examples.title: Comprehensive Mechanics Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A 0.2 kg block compresses spring (k=800 N/m) by 0.1 m on 30° incline (μ_k=0.2). After release, it slides 2 m then hits and sticks to 0.8 kg sphere (R=0.05 m) at incline bottom. Calculate: (a) Speed before collision, (b) Angular velocity after collision, (c) Distance sphere rolls before stopping.

step_by_step.explanation: Spring energy converted to kinetic minus friction work: $\frac{1}{2}kx^2 - \mu_k mg\cos\theta \cdot d = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$
Inelastic collision: momentum conserved, $mv = (M+m)v_{CM}$, $0.2 \times 5.76 = 1.0 \times v_{CM} \Rightarrow v_{CM} = 1.152$ m/s
Initial condition: $v_{CM} = 1.152$ m/s, $R\omega = 0.05 \times 72 = 3.6$ m/s, so $v_{CM} < R\omega$ - backward slipping
Translational: $a = f_k/(M+m) = 1.96$ m/s², Rotational: $\alpha = -f_kR/I = -122.5$ rad/s², Set $v_{CM} = R\omega$: $1.152 + 1.96t = 0.05(72 - 122.5t)$
$v_f = 1.152 + 1.96 \times 0.303 = 1.746$ m/s, distance = average velocity × time = $1.449 \times 0.303 = 0.439$ m during transition, plus rolling distance after

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Speed before collision = 5.76 m/s, (b) Angular velocity after collision = 72.0 rad/s, (c) Complex motion with slipping transition - sphere travels approximately 0.44 m during transition to pure rolling, then continues rolling. Demonstrates multi-stage problem with energy, momentum, and rolling dynamics.

worked_examples.title: Experimental Design: Testing Mechanical Principles
worked_examples.problem: Design an experiment to simultaneously test: (a) Conservation of mechanical energy, (b) Conservation of angular momentum, (c) Relationship between torque and angular acceleration. Specify equipment, procedure, measurements, and expected results.

step_by_step.explanation: Use a rotating platform with variable moment of inertia, applied torques, and energy measurements
Low-friction rotating platform, known masses with adjustable positions, spring scale or known weights for torque, motion sensors, data acquisition system
Apply known work via constant torque, measure final rotational speed, verify $W = \Delta K_{rot} = \frac{1}{2}I\omega^2$
Spin platform at known ω, pull masses inward, measure new ω, verify $I_1\omega_1 = I_2\omega_2$
Apply known torque, measure angular acceleration, verify $\tau = I\alpha$
Angular positions vs time, applied forces, mass positions, rotational velocities, moments of inertia
All three principles should be verified within experimental error, demonstrating consistency of classical mechanics
Account for friction, measurement uncertainties, air resistance, and systematic errors

worked_examples.final_answer: A comprehensive experiment using a rotating platform can test all three principles: energy conservation from work input, angular momentum conservation with changing configuration, and torque-acceleration relationship. Expected results should verify classical mechanics principles within experimental uncertainties, with discrepancies revealing effects of friction and other non-ideal factors.

common_misconceptions: Thinking conservation laws are independent rather than connected
Confusing conditions for different types of motion
Thinking rotational and translational motion are separate
Confusing when to use different reference points
Underestimating the importance of constraints in connected systems
real_world_applications: Renewable energy systems and turbine design
summary: This comprehensive review integrates all major classical mechanics concepts: kinematics (motion description), dynamics (Newton's laws), energy methods (work-energy theorem, conservation), momentum principles (linear and angular conservation), and rotational motion (torque, moment of inertia, rolling). Mastery involves solving complex multi-step problems, designing experiments, and understanding the interconnected nature of these fundamental principles. Systematic approaches, deliberate practice, and multiple assessment methods ensure solid preparation for advanced topics including Lagrangian mechanics, continuum mechanics, and engineering applications. The unified understanding developed here - that mechanical behavior follows predictable patterns governed by fundamental laws - forms the foundation for all physical sciences and engineering disciplines.
